topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 2.0: Patching and Update Process

body.p: This document provides a general description of the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade patching and update processes.

Instructions for deploying a specific patch or update are provided in README file that comes with the patch or update. Also, the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade documentation site will also have instructions for deploying patches and updates.
body.section:
What is a patch?A patch is minor hotfix that addresses a particular defect for a specific build.
A patch has following characteristics:
Can update any file (such as: configuration, INI files, .sh files, and .yml files) on the lifecycle manager (before the cloud is deployed) or cloud nodes (after the cloud is deployed);
Can update a particular package on existing cloud;
Supports rollback;
Is idempotent;
Is sequential;
Does not introduce new variables to what the configuration processor has already generated (such as group_vars, and host_vars).
A patch consists of two files: metadata.tar.gz and Readme
metadata.tar.gz - contains Ansible roles in the following hierarchy
Note: Not all the sub-directories under the /roles/<patch-name> directory are mandatory except for the following:roles/<patch-name>/tasks/apply.yml roles/<patch-name>/tasks/rollback.yml roles/<patch-name>/defaults/main.yml (ok if empty)
Readme - contains pre-requisites, impacted files, instruction to apply the patch
Multiple patches can be bundled into a single script and all the patches can be applied or rolled-back using this script.
How to apply a patch
Each patch will contain a README file with full instructions on how to deploy that patch. Also, the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade documentation site will also have instructions for deploying each patch.
In general, the process for applying a patch includes:
Extracting. You can download and extract patch files from the Helion Distribution Network (HDN) to the lifecycle manager in the /var/hlm/clouds/<cloud-name>/patches/ directory. The patch files are usually named in the patches_<buildbumber>.tar.gz format.
The extracted patch files contain a subdirectory for each individual patch.
Applying all patches using following command: cd /var/hlm/clouds/<cloud-name>/patches/ && ./hlm_applypatches.sh
Applying a specific patch using following command: hlm patch -c <cloud-name> -n <patch name> -t <tiers>
Rolling back a specific patch using following commandhlm patch -c <cloud-name> -n <patch name> -t <tiers> -r
Using the lifecycle manager CLIhlm patch -c <cloud name> -n <patch name> -t <tiers>
root@cg-hlm:~/cg-hlm/hlm-build# hlm patch --help
NAME hlm-patch - Install a patch on cloud SYNOPSIS hlm patch -c <cloud name> -n <name> [-v <verbose>] [-r <rollback>] [-t <tier>]
DESCRIPTION Install a patch as an addon on an existing cloud. Requires a well formed patch created in a format as expected by the patch framework
OPTIONS --cloud, -c Specify name of the cloud to act upon.
--name, -n Specify name of patch
--verbose, -v Produce verbose output. Example: hlm deploy -c <cloudname> -v
--rollback, -r Indicate if you need to rollback existing patch.
--tier, -t Indicate tier to apply or rollback patch. Multiple tiers can be specified using colon (:) seperator. E.g. -t BASE-CCP-T1:BASE:CCP-CPX

section.title: Update
section.p: An update is a major hotfix or plugin which need to access variables not available in configuration processor variable repository (such as group_vars and host_vars).

ul.li: Introduces new variables not available in configuration processor repository (group_vars, host_vars);
Can update particular package on an existing cloud;

configure.json - Defines variables specific to the environment. These are typically variables required by the update but not available in the variable repository (group_vars, host_vars) generated by configuration processor.

metadata.tar.gz - Contains Ansible roles, similar to that of a patch, which update the lifecycle manager or the cloud nodes. The Ansible roles can refer to group_vars and host_vars and any new variables defined in configure.json.
Readme - contains pre-requisites, impacted files, and instructions for applying the update.

section.p: Multiple updates cannot be bundled into a single script, because each update requires specific modifications in the configure.json file.

Each update will contain a README file with full instructions on how to deploy that update. Also, the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade documentation site will also have instructions for deploying each update.
In general, the process for applying an update includes:

li.p: Extracting. You can download and extract patch files from the Helion Distribution Network (HDN) to the lifecycle manager in the/var/hlm/clouds/<cloud-name>/updates/ directory. The update files are usually named in the updates<buildbumber>.tar.gz format. The extracted patch files contain a subdirectory for each individual update.

ul.li:
Applying an update using following steps:
modify the configuration file, <update-name>/configure.json, as stated in the README file included with the patch
apply the update using following commandhlm update -c <cloud name> -n <update name> -t <tiers>You can specify multiple tiers using -t <tier1>:<tier2>.
For example: hlm update -c mycloud -n NOV_HCG-890 -t BASE-CCP-T1:BASE-CPX-CCP
Rolling back an update using following command:hlm update -c <cloud name> -n <patch name> -t <tiers> -r

p.codeblock:
hlm update -c <cloud name> -n <name> [-v <verbose>] [-r <rollback>] [-t <tier>]
DESCRIPTION Install a update as an add-on on an existing cloud. Requires a well formed update created in a format as expected by the update framework
OPTIONS --cloud, -c Specify name of the cloud to act upon.
--name, -n Specify name of update
--verbose, -v Produce verbose output. Example: hlm deploy -c <cloudname> -v
--rollback, -r Indicate if you need to rollback existing update.
--tier, -t Indicate tier to apply or rollback patch.

section.title: Update log
section.p: An update log is maintained in update.txt in the /var/hlm/clouds/<cloud-name>/updates/ directory .
This file maintains updates applied and rolled-back to the environment and the corresponding time-stamp.
